<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

There have been many advancements in the voice model space in the last few months—Cartesia, Deepgram, ElevenLabs and Inworld AI to name a few. BYOK for language model chat has been fantastic, and it would be great to also enable BYOK for VS Code Speech so that more capable models with higher quality translation and better multilingual support are available for use in GitHub Copilot.

title: Todos don't truncate with elipses

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

title: Improve UX for clicking on todos in Copilot task view
body: Currently, clicking on a todo item in the Copilot task view does not trigger any action. From a user perspective, it would be more intuitive if clicking a todo navigated to a relevant point in the task history. For example: * If the todo has already been started, clicking could scroll to where it began in the history. * If the todo is completed, clicking could scroll to the point where it was marked finished. * If multiple relevant locations exist, the system could prioritize completion first, then start. This would make the todo list more interactive and useful for quickly locating context without manually scanning through the history. **Acceptance Criteria:** * Clicking a todo item scrolls or navigates to a meaningful location in the history. * Works for both in-progress and completed todos.

title: Disabling Copilot code completions doesn't stop inline suggestions
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.372.0
- VS Code Version: 1.104.1
- OS Version: 15.6.1
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): inline suggestions
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT 4.1
- Logs:
```
2025-09-23 15:12:31.461 [info] [certificates] Remo

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4d6a16fb-b2ed-41a0-a5ef-fdf5cfe19ce6

ved 15 expired certificates
2025-09-23 15:12:32.709 [info] [fetcher] Using Helix fetcher.
2025-09-23 15:12:32.709 [info] [code-referencing] Public code references are enabled.
2025-09-23 15:12:32.892 [info] [fetcher] Using Helix fetcher.
2025-09-23 15:13:14.768 [warning] [relatedFiles] unknown language shellscript
2025-09-23 15:13:15.038 [info] [fetchCompletions] Request 4219172b-79be-4513-87c2-a9793a12f7ba at <https://proxy.individual.githubcopilot.com/v1/engines/gpt-41-copilot/completions> finished with 200 status after 255.06333399999858ms
2025-09-23 15:13:15.504 [info] [streamChoices] solution 2 returned. finish reason: [stop]
2025-09-23 15:13:15.506 [info] [streamChoices] solution 1 returned. finish reason: [stop]
2025-09-23 15:13:15.508 [info] [streamChoices] solution 0 returned. finish reason: [stop]
2025-09-23 15:13:15.719 [info] [fetchCompletions] Request 47f42b2d-e272-4bfa-a078-2bc0c0320caf at <https://proxy.individual.githubcopilot.com/v1/engines/gpt-41-copilot/completions> finished with 200 status after 195.32633299999725ms
2025-09-23 15:13:15.777 [info] [streamChoices] solution 0 returned. finish reason: [stop]
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Disable Copilot suggestions in the bottom right (it should slow a slash through the icon)
2. Type code to get inline suggestions, example:
  3. Create a bash file
  4. Add the following code
```
remove_json_comments() {
      file=$1
}
```
3. Put your cursor after $1 and press enter, wait a second and inline suggestions will appear
4. To repeat: press backspace twice to put your cursor after $1 again, press enter and inline suggestions will appear again

Note that all the completion usage shown in the Copilot dashboard has been from these automatic completions, I haven't manually triggered any.

Things tried:
1. Restarting VS Code doesn't work
2. The only thing that worked is disabling the extension itself, but disabling code completions in the bottom right should work too, and this isn't a viable workaround because I may want to use other features.

title: fix(snap): detect Wayland socket under XDG_RUNTIME_DIR for Fedora
body:
The proposed change fixes a Wayland detection issue in the VS Code snap launcher on Fedora and similar distributions. Currently, the script only checks for the Wayland socket in the parent runtime directory ($XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/../$WAYLAND_DISPLAY), which causes Wayland to be incorrectly marked unavailable when the socket is actually in $XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/$WAYLAND_DISPLAY. This patch updates the script to check both locations and enable Wayland if either exists, creating a symlink only when needed. The change ensures correct Wayland detection, maintains backward compatibility, avoids breaking existing setups, and allows VS Code and other applications to properly use Wayland instead of falling back to X11, with minimal and safe modifications to the launcher script.

title: Implement welcome view rendering scheduler to prevent reentrant calls
body:
Take 2 at fixing: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/267105

Previous attempt https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/267856 was [reverted](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/268002) because first chat request in an empty window was not being rendered. This was because the chat list visibility was controlled by the welcomeView rendering logic. When the welcome view rendering was scheduled from within in `onDidChangeItems`, the chat list view visibility was not updated before the chat tree was progressively rendered which caused the first request to be missed.

In this pr, additional to the logic in #267856, I also moved out the logic to toggle visibility of the welcome/chatList view out of the welcome rendering logic here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/268023/files#diff-1a26fc97bbf0d39b6d25ad9fe509fad4d90373118985b50709f99b6ef5bde8c9R935

And update it here inside `onDidChangeItems` : https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/268023/files#diff-1a26fc97bbf0d39b6d25ad9fe509fad4d90373118985b50709f99b6ef5bde8c9R884

cc: @justschen

title: edits: allow keep/undo during an agent response
body:
Only disable keep/undo for an editor if it's currently streaming in
edits. Allow global keep all/undo all during an agent response, but just
exclude any entries currently streaming in edits when that happens.

Closes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/255464

title: Enterprise Policy Support for chat.disableAIFeatures
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Version: 1.104.1
OS: MacOS/Windows
Extensions: N/A

For environments with strict compliance requirements we need to be able to disable AI features globally using AD group policies or MDM tools.  I would expect something like `ChatDisableAIFeatures` to be in this list: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/enterprise#_centrally-manage-vs-code-settings.  From the documentation and the source it doesn't look like this is currently supported, and I can't find an existing feature request for it.  I can see some of the config params include a `policy` attr here but `chat.disableAIFeatures` does not: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chat.contribution.ts#L656

This would be a useful feature for compliance driven environments that restrict use of cloud-based AI services and might otherwise have to block use of VSCode.

body:
Type: Bug I was working on adding a feature when Copilot switched to responding in French and gave feedback that appeared to be from another chat with a different person, because it talked about controlling hardware whereas my company only works on software. ```Read ThankYou.tsx, lines 40 to 80 Now I need to understand how this component receives props. Let me check if there's a firstName or customerName prop in the types, and if not, I need to add it: Read types.ts Parfait ! J'ai centralisé toute la logique de contrôle de la lampe dans la fonction _updateDetectorZeroLampState(). Voici les améliorations apportées : Modifications réalisées : 1. Fonction _updateDetectorZeroLampState() centralisée Gère maintenant tous les états de la lampe : Mode manuel de service → UI_LED_OFF Mode automatique avec angle ≠ 0 → UI_LED_FLASH Mode automatique avec angle = 0 → UI_LED_ON 2. Simplification de setManualMotionForServicePurpose() Suppression des appels directs à OUI_GP_SetLamp() Appel systématique à _updateDetectorZeroLampState() après changement de mode Code plus simple et maintenable 3. Simplification des autres fonctions Suppression des vérifications !isManualMotionSelected() dans _updateBeamImageReference() et _processDetectorMotion() Appel direct à _updateDetectorZeroLampState() lors des changements d'angle Avantages de cette approche : ✅ Logique centralisée : Tout le contrôle de la lampe est dans une seule fonction ✅ Code plus maintenable : Modifications futures n'affectent qu'un seul endroit ✅ Moins de duplication : Suppression des vérifications répétées du mode manuel ✅ Plus robuste : La logique complète est appliquée à chaque changement d'état ✅ Plus lisible : La fonction _updateDetectorZeroLampState() documente clairement le comportement attendu Cette refactorisation rend le code plus propre et plus facile à maintenir, tout en conservant exactement le même comportement fonctionnel.``` Extension version: 0.31.2 VS Code version: Code 1.104.0 (Universal) (f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260, 2025-09-10T06:46:18.035Z) OS version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 Modes:

title: Chat - switch chat toolbar to use overlay widget
body: This pull request switches the chat session toolbar to use an overlay widget so that we can take advantage of stacking overlay widgets in the lower right hand corner in order to address the edge case in which both the chat session toolbar is being shown as well as the "editor content button" (ex: Resolve in Merge Editor). PR also contains a drive-by fix for stacking overlay widgets in the top/bottom right corners.

title: Copy selection for deleted chunk in inline diff
body:
An attempt to fix #8226 

Hi @hediet , can I interest you with (yet another) PR for #8226, a.k.a. inline diff deleted chunk copy selection? :)

The main idea is to calculate the exact line and column for the start & end of the selection in a view zone, and extract the corresponding code chunk using the text model API.

Demo: 
![copySelectionInlineDelete](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1b64cec2-aed4-4e39-9b5f-854cf3f06c83)

This works with both the menu item, and the browser 'copy' event (Ctrl/Cmd+C).

I have put the setup in a reusable method in a separate file, following the example of [renderLines.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/editor/browser/widget/diffEditor/components/diffEditorViewZones/renderLines.ts)

Due to the view zone, there are some hackery involved to get those line and column numbers right (the line number extraction is the same as that from the [inlineDiffDeletedCodeMargin.ts](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/editor/browser/widget/diffEditor/components/diffEditorViewZones/inlineDiffDeletedCodeMargin.ts)). Let me know if you see any issues, or if you prefer to solve it in a different way.

Thanks!

title: `getCopilotToken()` is slow due to `getAnyGitHubSession()`

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: polish
labels.description: Cleanup and polish issue

labels.name: chat-authentication
labels.description: Issues specifically about authenticating in Chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Every time someone calls `getCopilotToken()` we first run `getAnyGitHubSession()` here:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/f2d8f317d77cb923838dad823b6db99640f057d9/src/platform/authentication/common/authentication.ts#L217

Even though the copilot token is cached, this call is very slow as it uses vscode API and reaches into the renderer process. We measured it in some completions/nes scenarios and saw that this call takes between `20ms` and `120ms`. This has a huge impact on features like completions and NES which need to run very fast.

Is this even needed as this code also runs in the copilot token manager when the token is invalidated?

title: VS Code Microsoft account sync unexpectedly registers account in Windows

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: upstream
labels.description: Issue identified as 'upstream' component related (exists outside of VS Code)

labels.name: authentication-microsoft
labels.description: Issues with the Microsoft Authentication extension

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.1
- OS Version: W11 26100.6584

I use my personal Microsoft account at work in order to sync my extensions and settings.
At work, I log in with a local session, and I also have a professional email address to access the company’s SharePoint.

After adding my personal account in VS Code, it became visible across the whole computer. Since then, OneDrive opens two sessions and suggests signing in with my personal Microsoft account registered in VS Code, probably treating it as a local account. My email address is also visible in the folder %localappdata%/Microsoft/OneAuth.

After deleting this folder, as well as IdentityCache, I was of course signed out of my account in VS Code. 

**Steps to Reproduce**

1. Sign in to VS Code with a personal Microsoft account (used to sync extensions and settings).
2. Work on a machine where you log in with a local Windows session.
3. Notice that after adding the account in VS Code, it becomes visible system-wide.
4. OneDrive now opens two sessions and suggests signing in with the personal Microsoft account registered in VS Code (likely treating it as a local account).
5. Check `%localappdata%/Microsoft/OneAuth` → the personal email address is stored there.
6. Delete the `OneAuth` and `IdentityCache` folders.

**Actual Behavior**

* The personal Microsoft account added in VS Code propagates to the whole system.
* OneDrive automatically tries to use that account and opens duplicate sessions.
* After deleting `OneAuth` and `IdentityCache`, VS Code is signed out.

**Expected Behavior**

* Signing into VS Code with a personal Microsoft account should remain scoped to VS Code only.
* It should not expose or register the account system-wide in Windows or OneDrive.

**Environment**

* Local Windows session (not a domain account).
* Professional Microsoft account also used for SharePoint access.
* VS Code with personal Microsoft account for sync.

title: Copilot Chat Ignores User Instructions to Avoid Modifying Existing Code, Leading to Repeated Unwanted Changes and Reverts
body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.31 (2025-09-10)
- VS Code Version: 1.104.1 (system setup)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045
- Feature: Edit mode (file editing via chat)
- Selected model: Grok Code Fast 1 (Preview)
- Logs: See attached chat history document for full conversation logs.

For whatever reason the logs created from the Copilot Chat Debug aren't showing from the beginning of the chat.
See markdown log for complete chat history.

[logs.chatreplay.json](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22496263/logs.chatreplay.json)

[logs.chat.md](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22496372/logs.chat.md)

#### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Initiate a chat session in VS Code with Copilot Chat enabled, focusing on editing a PowerShell script file (e.g., file.ps1).
2. Provide initial requirements for modifying the script, including constraints like "do not alter existing code" or "only add functions without changing other parts."
3. Observe that Copilot suggests or applies edits that modify existing code structures (e.g., replacing loops, changing formatting, or altering logic outside specified areas).
4. Respond with corrections or rejections, explicitly stating not to change the original code.
5. Note that Copilot continues to propose or apply changes to the original code in subsequent responses, requiring multiple reverts (e.g., 7 times in this case, as reviewed in the chat history).
6. Attempt to revert changes manually or via chat, but the tool may inconsistently preserve or restore the original code, leading to further issues like missing lines or formatting discrepancies.

#### Expected Behavior:
Copilot should strictly adhere to user-specified constraints (e.g., "do not alter existing code") and only modify or add code as explicitly allowed. Reverts should fully restore the original file state without introducing new issues.

#### Actual Behavior:
Despite repeated user reminders (e.g., "you've been told at least 10 times not to change"), Copilot modifies existing code, changes formatting (e.g., removing newlines), replaces loops with functions, or alters logic outside the intended scope. This results in a cycle of changes and reverts, frustrating the user and potentially corrupting the file (e.g., losing 39 lines in one revert). The chat history shows this pattern persisting across multiple interactions, with the AI acknowledging the issue but continuing to violate constraints.

#### Additional Context:
The attached chat history provides a detailed log of the conversation, demonstrating the repeated violations. The user explicitly avoided nesting if statements, else clauses, and other style preferences, but Copilot ignored these and broader directives like "do not alter anything more." This suggests a potential issue with how Copilot interprets or enforces user constraints in edit mode, possibly related to the Grok model or the edit tool's logic.

title: Terminal auto-approve should parse shell command arguments for more granular trust
body:
The terminal's command approval feature doesn't inspect the arguments passed to shell executables like `pwsh.exe`, `bash`, etc. When GitHub Copilot suggests a command that wraps an actual command in a shell-invoking syntax (e.g., `pwsh.exe -Command "dotnet test path_to_csproj"`), the approval mechanism only recognizes `pwsh.exe` as the command, not the `dotnet test` part inside the string.

This leads to a poor user experience and a potential security issue. To use the auto-approve feature effectively, the user is forced to add the shell executable itself (e.g., `pwsh.exe`) to the allowed list. This effectively disables the security check for *any* command executed through that shell, undermining the purpose of the feature.

The desired behavior would be for the approval system to be intelligent enough to parse the command line, identify the actual command being executed within the shell's argument, and check *that* command against the approval list.

#### **Steps to Reproduce:**

1.  Add a specific, safe command to the list of approved commands in your settings. For example, add `dotnet test` to `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove`.
2.  Have Copilot execute a command in the following format:
    ```powershell
    pwsh.exe -Command "dotnet test C:/proj/proj.csproj"
    ```

#### **Expected Behavior**

The command executes without a security prompt because the core command being run, `dotnet test`, is already on the approved list.

#### **Actual Behavior**

A security prompt appears asking whether to trust this command. The system fails to recognize that the underlying command is the already-approved `dotnet test`. This forces the user to either:
a) Enable auto-approve for `pwsh.exe` itself, which would allow any future command run via `pwsh.exe -Command` to execute without a prompt.
b) Enable auto-approve for the exact command, which would be problematic, because there may be a lot of different parameters passed to `dotnet test`.
c) Manually approve the command every time, which makes the auto-approve feature redundant for this common, AI-generated pattern.

#### **Proposed Solution**

I propose that the terminal's trust mechanism be enhanced to detect and parse commands for common shell execution patterns. It should look for patterns such as:

  * `pwsh.exe -Command "[COMMAND]"`
  * `powershell.exe -Command "[COMMAND]"`
  * `bash -c "[COMMAND]"`
  * `sh -c "[COMMAND]"`
  * `zsh -c "[COMMAND]"`
  * `cmd.exe /c "[COMMAND]"`

When one of these patterns is detected, the trust validation should be performed on the `[COMMAND]` part, not on the shell executable.

-----

#### **Regarding Existing Workarounds**

I am aware that this issue can be partially mitigated by using regular expressions in the `chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove` setting. However, this approach is not a sufficient solution for two main reasons:

1.  **Poor User Experience:** It requires users to write and maintain potentially complex regular expressions. The goal of the trust feature should be convenience and security that is accessible through the UI (e.g., the confirmation prompt), not just through advanced configuration in `settings.json`.
2.  **Redundancy:** To be comprehensive, a user would need to define the same core command multiple times for different shells. For instance, allowing `dotnet test` would require separate regex entries for `pwsh.exe -Command "dotnet test"`, `bash -c "dotnet test"`, `cmd.exe /c "dotnet test"`, etc. The ideal solution is to approve a command like `dotnet test` **once**, and have the system recognize it regardless of the shell wrapper.

A native implementation of this parsing logic would provide a much more robust, secure, and user-friendly experience out-of-the-box, especially as AI-assisted terminal usage becomes more common.
